top.data: Digital Pali Reader - Help File
If you are reading this, you have most likely got the Pali Reader up and
running on your computer. If it is up but not running, maybe this document
will help.
Notes:
<ul>
<li><font face="Century Gothic">The reader was created for my own personal use, but anyone is welcome to use
or distribute what I have made for their own benefit or the benefit of others.
<li><font face="Century Gothic">Some of the words 'recognized' by the reader are still incorrectly so, and many more are not yet recognized.
Please bear with me, I will try to correct this as I have time.
<hr>
What is it?
The Digital Pali Reader (DPR) is a tool, much like a hard-copy language reader, facilitating study of the Pali language at an
advanced level. Rather than offering a translation for the text being
read, a reader usually includes a dictionary with all of the difficult words
found in the reader. The DPR differs from an ordinary reader in several
respects:
<ol>
<li><font face="Century Gothic">The DPR allows for instant lookup of words, simply by clicking on a word
in the passage being read. This avoids time spent looking for the word
in a hard-copy dictionary or in another place on one's computer.

• The DPR has a built in search function similar to that of the CSCD. Whereas the CSCD allows for only global searches or searches of entire pitakas, the DPR provides Nikaya and Book searches as well.
<li><font face="Century Gothic">The dictionary files in the DPR were not designed specifically for the
purpose at hand, and of course word-to-definition matches are sometimes incorrect
due to imperfect
analysis.

• The DPR includes several dictionaries: Pali-English, English-Pali, Pali proper names, and Concise Pali Dictionary, as well as a searchable compilation of terms discussed in the commentaries. These can be directly accessed from the control panel under the "Dictionary" section.
<li><font face="Century Gothic">The DPR has several useful auxiliary utilities, including:
<ul>
• bookmark and quote clipboard for keeping important passages
• A Pali conversion utility that converts to and from Velthius, Unicode, CSCD, and Thai scripts
• extensible transliteration of Pali script into other scripts; Thai is included, others are in the works
• Grammar texts and tools for brushing up on Pali grammar, as well as a Pali language quiz to test your vocabulary
• Random English quotes from Buddhavacana, by S. Dhammika
While the DPR is far from perfect, it is sure to be useful for intermediate Pali students
who wish to advance their studies to a higher level.
<hr>
How to Use:
(Note: If any problem arises in the functioning of the reader, just click on the "Don't Panic" button (or press CTRL+F5) to reset the reader)

The right side of the screen contains the main controls. Basic use should require little explanation, and some of the advanced controls are still in an experimental stage. What follows is a brief explanation of all of the controls in the right frame:
<ul>
<li><font face="Century Gothic">At the top, there is the list of nikayas, books and sub-sections for
each book.
<li><font face="Century Gothic">Below that, there are some buttons

for bringing up the section for analysis <input type="button" class="btn" value="Go" title="Retrieve the section for analysis" accesskey="g">, and two previous <input type="button" class="btn" value="<" title="Retrieve last section"> and next <input type="button" class="btn" value=">" title="Retrieve next section"> buttons. Below that are a button bringing up the original velthius pali
of the current selection, one for reading the commentaries to those collections which have commentaries included, and one to switch between the installed scripts (currently Thai and Roman).
<li><font face="Century Gothic">Next below that, There is a section titled
"Bookmarks".
The first row here contains a drop-down list of saved bookmarks and a button
<input type="button" class="btn" value=">" title="Load this bookmark">. To open a saved bookmark, including the scrolled distance, select
a bookmark from the list and click on the button.
The second row contains a text field and a button <input type="button" class="btn" value="S" title="Set Bookmark">. To create a
bookmark for the current page and scrolled distance, type in a name for the
bookmark and click on the button . As an option, if you first select some text, that text will be added to the bookmark in the bookmark list.
Note: Clicking on the title "Bookmarks" opens up an advanced bookmark manager where you can view/add descriptions, change names, and delete bookmarks.
<li><font face="Century Gothic">Next below that, there is the search function and a manual dictionary
lookup.

To use the search function, first select a nikaya and book (optionally) at the top (changing the other fields doesn't affect the search), switch to mula or atthakatha, enter the string for which to search (or multiple strings seperated

by the "+" sign) and then click on either <input type="button" class="btn" value="T" title="Search through the entire mul or att filelist">, <input type="button" class="btn" value="N" title="Search through the entire Nikāya">, or <input type="button" class="btn" value="B" title="Search through the entire book"> buttons under "Text Search".

<input type="button" class="btn" value="T" title="Search through the entire mul or att filelist"> searches the entire mula or atthakatha filelist, <input type="button" class="btn" value="N" title="Search through the entire Nikāya"> searches an entire Nikaya, and

searches an entire book.

To search for a page number, use the following syntax: P1.0001, P1.0002, etc., where "P" (or V, M, T) is the PTS pagination set, the first "1" is the volume, and the following (must be four digits) is the page number. After entering the page code, click "B" to search the current book, or "N" for the current nikāya.
<li>The manual dictionary lookup has six choices. "DPR" runs an analysis on the word or passage at hand as it normally would. This only works for full words and phrases.
"ATT" (Atthakathā) brings up a list of words or phrases explained in the commentaries.
"PED" (Pali-English Dictionary), "EPD" (English-Pali), "DPN" (Dictionary of Pali Proper Names), and "CPD" (Concise Pali Dictionary) bring up entries in the selected dictionary

beginning with the letter sequence as it is typed. If you choose "PED" and type "aa" into the box, for example, it will come up with a list of Pali-English Dictionary entries starting with a long "ā". The CPD allows multiple language translations from Pali, provided that the appropriate dictionary file has been installed (see instructions above).
<li><font face="Century Gothic">The right-most column contains a variety of buttons, divided into
sections.

The buttons in the topmost section (<input type="button" class="btn" value="R" title="Maximize Read Frame" accesskey="r"><input type="button" class="btn" value="A" title="Restore to Analysis Mode" accesskey="a"><input type="button" class="btn" value="D" title="Maximize dIctionary Frame" accesskey="i"><input type="button" class="btn" value="L" title="Maximize aLgorithm Frame" accesskey="l">) adjust the layout of the rows
in the left column. The reader currently allows for four different
views: = Reading view, = Analysis view, = Dictionary View, = Algorithm View.

The buttons in the second section (<input type="button" class="btn" value="D" title="Bring up the Definitions" accesskey="d"><input type="button" class="btn" value="C" title="Bring up the Converter" accesskey="c"><input type="button" class="btn" value="T" title="Bring up the Textbox" accesskey="s">) switch the bottom-left frame

between three utilities: <input type="button" class="btn" value="D" title="Bring up the Definitions" accesskey="d"> the dictionaries, <input type="button" class="btn" value="C" title="Bring up the Converter" accesskey="c"> a CSCD > Unicode <>
Velthius Pali text convertor, and a multi-purpose text box.

The buttons in the third section (<input type="button" class="btn" value="v" title="Scroll to bookmark"><input type="button" class="btn" value="#" title="Get current location for bookmark"><input type="button" class="btn" value="^" title="Go to top">) allow one to set a scroll point

<input type="button" class="btn" value="#" title="Get current location for bookmark">, scroll to that point <input type="button" class="btn" value="v" title="Scroll to bookmark">, and scroll to the top <input type="button" class="btn" value="^" title="Go to top"> of the current
section. This is useful for long sections.

The buttons in the next section (<input type="button" class="btn" value="G" title="Open Grammar (New Window)"><input type="button" class="btn" value="C" title="Open Cheat Sheet (New Window)"><input type="button" class="btn" value="N" title="Open DPPN (New Window)"><input type="button" class="btn" value="T" title="Open Grammar Tools (New Window)"><input type="button" class="btn" value="L" title="Open Links (New Window)">) bring up various other pages, including <input type="button" class="btn" value="G" title="Open Grammar (New Window)"> Duroiselle's Pali

Grammar, <input type="button" class="btn" value="C" title="Open Cheat Sheet (New Window)"> Alan McClure's Pali Cheat Sheet, <input type="button" class="btn" value="N" title="Open DPPN (New Window)"> the Dictionary of Pali
Proper Names, some grammar tools, and links to other Pali-related websites.

In the second-to-last section, there are two buttons () that allow one to adjust the size (in pixels) of the different parts of the screen (especially useful for very small or very large screens) and the text colors used for various parts of the reader. There is also an option in the configuration screen to disable to Access To Insight translation links. Pressing the "X" button resets the values to their originals.

The buttons in the final section () are more extras: a Pali quiz using the CPD (multiple languages available via the language packs above), a quote of the moment from Ven. Dhammika's Buddha Vacana, this help file, a form to contact me directly, and a button to restart the reader in case anything goes wrong.
Once you have retrieved a section, click on any
word as you read through to bring up an analysis of the word and hopefully at least one (hopefully correct) definition from one of the three dictionaries.

Gratitude:

Thanks first and foremost to Alexander Genaud, without whom I would still be pulling my hair out (figuratively) waiting for the script to load a single section. Without his initial help there would be no DPR.
Without his later advice we would still be accessing one paragraph at a time and
the data would be pre-analyzed and thus difficult to read. There would also be
no search function. Special thanks also to Alan McClure, Ven. Gavesako, Peter

Masefield, Lin Qian, and Leland George for spotting errors in the script and offering encouragement and suggestions. Thanks to Upaasako, our first team member who helped with the bookmarking system among other things. Thanks to John Bullit for his link on www.accesstoinsight.org. And thanks to everyone else who helped out in the project in any small or large way - sotthi vo hotu. Special impersonal credit is due to all of those people involved in creating and providing publicly-available electronic versions of the following resources:
<ul>
• The Sixth(?) Council Tipitaka
• The Pali English Dictionary
• Concise Pali English Dictionary
• Concise English Pali Dictionary
• Dictionary of Pali Proper Names
• A Practical Grammar of the PƒÅli Language
• Buddha Vacana

Should this software infringe upon anyone's felt right to forbid the copying of any of the above or other materials, I apologize for the felt violation. I am sorry to know that some people feel this way about generally useful things that benefit the public immensely when distributed freely. May all be happy and well.
</font><hr>
Final Words:
